channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: The Week Ahead: March 22
item.description: but will it finally show up in the data? Earth Hour, when people are encouraged to shut off lights for an hour, is also Saturday night. cuz Passover starts Saturday evening.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Covid Causes More Calendar Chaos
item.description: The Tokyo Olympics will bar international spectators from attending the event, which is set to start on July 23.    We've got too many people and too many looking to act out while there's a pandemic going on,” Mayor Dan Gelber told USA Today.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: What This Railroad Merger Means for North American Trade
item.description: Yesterday, railroad operator Canadian Pacific announced plans to acquire Kansas City Southern for ~$25 billion.  Zoom out: The deal is a bet that North American trade will come roaring back as economies and factories flicker back to life.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Three New Hard Seltzers Are Here For Spring
item.description: Zoom out: We’ll find out soon whether post-Covid life is more American Pie or apple pie, but expect hard seltzer to play a big role either way: Research company Bernstein estimates hard seltzer will make up more than 15% of the beer and cider market by 2024.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: March 20
item.description: You can also buy individual fart recordings for $85 a toot. (Hakai Magazine)  Read: Tuna’s last stand.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: China Adds Restrictions on Tesla for Security Reasons
item.description: The Chinese government is putting the Technoking on notice. If you’re having déjà vu, it’s because the White House has blocked Chinese tech companies from operating in the US due to similar concerns over snooping.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Vaccine Tracker: March 20
item.description: Third waves: The German health minister warned that Covid-19 cases are rising at an “exponential rate” and the pace of the vaccine rollout isn’t fast enough to prevent a third wave. we’re getting close to half a billion vaccine doses administered. Paris entered lockdown mode yesterday.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The Business of March Madness
item.description: For schools: The NCAA has a pool of money that factors in results of the men’s tournament, dishing out one “unit” for each game a team plays until the Final Four. The women’s tournament isn’t revenue-generating, according to the NCAA.  The tournament is big moneyFor the NCAA: The D1 men’s tournament accounted for 79% of the $1.1 billion the organization brought in during the 2019 fiscal year. For context, Legal Sports Report estimated that $462.4 million was legally wagered on this year’s Super Bowl.   The women’s tournament kicks off tomorrow in a “bubble” in San Antonio.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: World Happiness Report Announces Good News
item.description: Researchers cite a comparatively successful response to Covid and a high level of social trust as reasons why this region ranked high, because it’s definitely not the balmy weather.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.description: For schools: The NCAA has a pool of money that factors in results of the men’s tournament, dishing out one “unit” for each game a team plays until the Final Four. The women’s tournament isn’t revenue-generating, according to the NCAA.  The tournament is big moneyFor the NCAA: The D1 men’s tournament accounted for 79% of the $1.1 billion the organization brought in during the 2019 fiscal year. For context, Legal Sports Report estimated that $462.4 million was legally wagered on this year’s Super Bowl.   The women’s tournament kicks off tomorrow in a “bubble” in San Antonio.

item.title: What's the Hype Around Air Fryers?
item.description: A few years later, van der Weij licensed the tech to Philips, which debuted the first modern air fryer at a consumer electronics show in Berlin in 2010.  But what is an air fryer? But here’s where the genius of van der Weij comes in: Air fryers get your food nice and crispy without the oil bath. The recommendation site Wirecutter put the air fryer on its “Worst Things for Most People” list. Basically, an air fryer pummels your food with hot air circulated by a high-speed fan. The pandemic, and the millions of new home chefs it spawned, may have anointed the air fryer kitchen royalty. You encounter the Maillard reaction when you eat all kinds of delicious foods, including campfire-roasted marshmallows, seared steaks, and french fries.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Super Nintendo World Opens in Osaka
item.description: Unfortunately for stateside Nintendo fans, Orlando's version of the park is still delayed until 2025, but you can virtually tour the attractions in Osaka on YouTube.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: March 19
item.description: (Cameron Wiese)  Read: Should we bring back the World's Fair? With shipments also headed to Mexico, this is the first time the US is sending vaccines abroad.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Supply Chains Need a Factory Reset
item.description: Bottom line: There isn't one primary driver of supply chain chaos—it's simply a series of unfortunate events. Demand for lumber by home builders has outstripped supply to the point where prices have shot up more than 180% since last spring. How about a wood shortage.  Got room for one more?
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: NFL Inks Huge New Media Deals
item.description: The details: Several of the NFL’s media partners (including CBS and NBC) will keep their current schedule. It’s the first time a streaming service has been granted an exclusive package of NFL games. The new deals will start up in 2023.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: SPACs Post Record Q1 and Exceed 2020 Dealmaking Total
item.description: If conditions don't improve, analysts said there's only a 35% chance they'll still be at Goldman in six months. Goldman Sachs bankers have become a little too familiar with their Zoom reflection. In the market, over 400 SPACs with $131 billion in cash are looking for companies to merge with. It's advised 32 SPACs in Q1 for $9.2 billion in proceeds, according to Refinitiv data. Only Citigroup's got it beat with 56 SPAC IPOs for $10.5 billion. And the SEC recently warned investors to treat celebrities' SPACs with the same skepticism as their Proactiv commercials.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Supply Chains Need a Factory Reset
item.description: Bottom line: There isn't one primary driver of supply chain chaos—it's simply a series of unfortunate events. Demand for lumber by home builders has outstripped supply to the point where prices have shot up more than 180% since last spring. How about a wood shortage.  Got room for one more?

item.title: SPACs Post Record Q1 and Exceed 2020 Dealmaking Total
item.description: If conditions don't improve, analysts said there's only a 35% chance they'll still be at Goldman in six months. It's advised 32 SPACs in Q1 for $9.2 billion in proceeds, according to Refinitiv data. Goldman Sachs bankers have become a little too familiar with their Zoom reflection. In the market, over 400 SPACs with $131 billion in cash are looking for companies to merge with.  Zoom out: As SPACs continue to IPO with huge valuations, analysts are still worried about market "indigestion." And the SEC recently warned investors to treat celebrities' SPACs with the same skepticism as their Proactiv commercials.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: March 19
item.description: (Cameron Wiese)  Read: Should we bring back the World's Fair? With shipments also headed to Mexico, other countries are receiving vaccines from the US for the first time.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: NFL Inks Huge New Media Deals
item.description: It’s the first time a streaming service has been granted an exclusive package of NFL games.  The details: Most of the NFL’s media partners (CBS, Fox, NBC, etc. The new deals will start up in 2023.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The Brew’s Weekly News Quiz: March 19
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: High Profile Endorsement Defections: Justin Long for Intel, LeBron James for PepsiCo
item.description: The backstory: Long is the latest pawn in Intel and Apple’s chip chess match. Basketball star LeBron James inked a deal with PepsiCo after working with Coca-Cola since he was 18 years old.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: March 18
item.description: Speaking at his company’s annual shareholders meeting, Samsung Co-CEO Koh Dong-jin warned that the global chip shortage will ding business performance.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Iceland Reopens to Non-EU Visitors
item.description: Previously, EU citizens could visit Iceland without quarantining, but now the country is opening up to those outside the bloc’s free-travel zone known as the Schengen area.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Snap Buys Fit Analytics to Bolster Its Fashion and E-Commerce Aspirations
item.description: Adding Fit Analytics opens the door for Snap to monetize through in-app purchases and reduce its reliance on ad dollars.  The company: Berlin-based Fit Analytics uses machine learning and customer-provided info to help shoppers find the right clothing size when ordering online.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Report: Global Gasoline Consumption Has Peaked
item.description: Ever since the Model T rolled off production lines, gasoline has been the primary fuel source to get from Point A to Point B.  One important note: The IEA does see a full recovery for global crude oil demand, which is used for everything from jet fuel to electricity generation—not just for gasoline.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Fed Boosts Economic Growth Projections, but Maintains Its Easy Money Strategy
item.description: If the Fed said things do look better, then it’s increasingly hard to justify its current strategy of ultra-loose monetary policy, which is when the Fed uses its tools (like lowering interest rates) to juice the economy when it’s in the dumps. That’s not us trying to impress our middle school readers—it’s a direct quote from the Federal Reserve’s highly anticipated policy statement yesterday.   As the US economy continues to rebound from its Covid-induced recession, the Fed projects GDP will grow 6.5% this year, a big jump from its previous estimate of 4.2% in December.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Snap Buys Fit Analytics to Bolster Its Fashion and E-Commerce Aspirations
item.description: Adding Fit Analytics opens the door for Snap to monetize through in-app purchases and reduce its reliance on ad dollars.  The company: Berlin-based Fit Analytics uses machine learning and customer-provided info to help shoppers find the right clothing size when ordering online.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: High Profile Endorsement Defections: Justin Long for Intel, LeBron James for PepsiCo
item.description: The backstory: Long is the latest pawn in Intel and Apple’s chip chess match. LeBron will be the face of Pepsi’s new morning energy drink, plus he will promote some of its other brands, and take part in the company’s social justice efforts. Now it is.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Iceland Reopens to Non-EU Visitors
item.description: Previously, EU citizens could visit Iceland without quarantining, but now the country is opening up to those outside the bloc’s free-travel zone known as the Schengen area.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: March 18
item.description: (Shaan Puri on Twitter) Read: Why Clubhouse will fail. Koh said that Samsung may even skip the introductions of its new Galaxy Note phone because of the lack of chips.

item.description: If the Fed said things do look better, then it’s increasingly hard to justify its current strategy of ultra-loose monetary policy, which is when the Fed uses its tools (like lowering interest rates) to juice the economy when it’s in the dumps. That’s not us trying to impress our middle school readers—it’s a direct quote from the Federal Reserve’s highly anticipated policy statement yesterday.   As the US economy continues to rebound from its Covid-induced recession, the Fed projects GDP will grow 6.5% this year, a big jump from its previous estimate of 4.2% in December.
